ygData.subject: Re: What's Natural About Interactive Evolution (Warning: LONG message)
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello, Let me talk about this a little. TBE does not limit the solution, it simply follows the same method of selection for mostly simple tasks - like - keep

Subject: Re: What's Natural About Interactive Evolution (Warning: LONG message)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=mkMd7GVdcJZMpAVSHqCYG4HKMUp_Dr6g6Hko3mNA1Ff-QkpFB5z-HhEdZA
X-Yahoo-Profile: petar_chervenski

Hello, 

Let me talk about this a little. TBE does not limit the solution, =
it 
simply follows the same method of selection for mostly simple tasks - 
=
like - keep the poles balanced or drive that car without crashing. 
This is=
 actually dependant of all possible solutions for the given 
problem at han=
d. You can't expect that a pole balancer can evolve a 
human-level AI, simp=
ly because the environment that hosts the 
evolution process is too simple.=
 
The key point in this is, what is possible in the task domain and how 
sm=
art the selection process can be? In nature, everything is 
possible. Excel=
lent advancements pop up and survive, but this is just 
because this is pos=
sible in nature. More freedom means more complex 
space to search and there=
fore, more power. 
The freedom in the picture drawing domain is enourmous. =
Anything can 
be drawn on a simple 2D plane! 
The selection in nature is ba=
sed on the performance of the actual 
phenotypes, but since that the nature=
 is a very complex world with a 
lot of chemistry, physics and ecologic rel=
ationships, this gives the 
process a new level of freedom.. How to explain=
 that?! 
A good evolutionary algorithm should consider good/bad indivuduals=
 
not compared to a static fitness function, but simply as these 
individua=
ls show what they are capable of! The problem is how to make 
the environme=
nt rich enough, so the phenotypes will be enabled to do 
various things, "e=
xperiment" in this environment. This is why IEC 
looks so great, because th=
e environment is the artist's perception of 
viewing a picture.  
Imagine a=
 virtual world where there are rules, stuff like physics for 
example. Crea=
tures evolving there may have any topology and survive 
not based on some f=
itness function like "who lives longer, is good", 
but simply as "show me w=
hat you can do".. The method of selection is 
therefore dependant every tim=
e, for every generation.. 
So, there is an idea. The system hosting the evo=
lution process should 
not choose the parents for the next generation. The =
individuals 
themselves should be the ones who decide! 
But I have no idea =
how to automate that without human interaction..   

Peter

--- In neat@yah=
oogroups.com, "PlaceboZA (Greg)" <placeboza@...> wrote:
>
> Good points, Th=
anks for that :)
> 
> A simplification (perhaps oversimplified) is that TBE=
:
>  - limits the solution, putting a ceiling on it's possibilities
>  - co=
mpletely ignores excellent advancements into other directions
>  - has diff=
iculty determining the short term goals in a complex 
target (e.g.
> can't =
determine what image looks  most like mona lisa when you've 
just
> started=
 breeding)
> 
> That's the key points for me anyway :)
> 
> Greg
> 
> On 8/=
13/07, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> >
> >   Derek and Jeff,
> >
=
> > I would be happy to expand on my controversial remarks on 
interactive
=
> > evolution being more "natural" than the usual kind of evolutionary
> > =
computation. I've been thinking about this issue for a couple 
years
> > so=
 it will be good to get some of it down. Please be warned this 
is
> > a lo=
ng argument, but hopefully you will find it interesting 
enough to
> > be w=
orth your time.
> >
> > First, let me make sure the terms are straight. I'm=
 comparing
> > interactive evolutionary computation (IEC), which means evol=
ution
> > with a human (or "breeder") in the loop, to regular evolutionary
=
> > computation, which means evolution with respect to a given fitness
> > =
function. I have begun to call the latter (at least to
> > myself) "target-=
based evolution" (TBE) because the fitness 
function
> > in effect describe=
s a target that a human designer is hoping to
> > reach, so I will use that=
 term here.
> >
> > Note that neither IEC nor TBE are really "natural" in t=
he sense 
that
> > natural evolution neither involved a sentient breeder ov=
erseeing 
the
> > process nor did it involve a predesignated target based o=
n which 
each
> > organism is always evaluated. The question then is which =
one is 
more
> > natural than the other, since neither one is truly natural=
.
> >
> > To get some perspective on this question, let's consider the 
sim=
ple
> > task that Colin proposed: Imagine that we set a particular desired
=
> > image as a target and evaluate against that. Could we then evolve 
a
> =
> CPPN (or ANN if you prefer) that produces the desired image?
> >
> > The =
answer is surprising (we've tried it!). It turns out to be 
very
> > hard w=
ith anything but the simplest of images. What you discover
> > quickly is t=
hat the fitness function isn't rewarding the right
> > things. The images t=
ends to devolve into a gray cloud that 
minimizes
> > error by choosing an =
intermediate shade- not what you want at all.
> >
> > Yet the issue is deep=
er than that. In fact, here is what is really
> > interesting: If you take =
any image (except the simplest ones) on
> > Picbreeder- images that were ev=
olved through IEC with NEAT- you 
will
> > not be able to evolve to those s=
ame images through TBE with NEAT! 
I
> > challenge anyone to disprove me on=
 this; I'd be very interested.
> >
> > That is a remarkable observation: NE=
AT can't reproduce it's own
> > results! The only conclusion is that the se=
lection method is the
> > culprit. That is, it has to do with how you decid=
e what's good in
> > any particular generation, which of course is differen=
t in IEC and
> > TBE.
> >
> > So let's look more closely at this issue: How=
 did we evolve images
> > interactively that could not be reached through r=
egular TBE? The
> > answer is that humans have a different way of rewarding=
 
intermediate
> > results. In particular, human breeders in IEC examine wh=
at is good
> > *in the present* and make their decision based on that where=
as TBE
> > compares what you have in the present to a long-term future goal=
.
> >
> > Perhaps if you've used Picbreeder or IEC you may think that you 
=
were
> > actually evolving to a target and thus that I am wrong. But
> > Pi=
cbreeder disproves this view. As soon as *someone else* branches
> > from y=
our image, whatever "target" you may have had in mind (if 
any)
> > is irre=
levant. They have their own ideas about what is good. So it
> > isn't possi=
ble that what the next person in the chain evolved was
> > your original in=
tent.
> >
> > On the other hand I may not need to go that far to make the p=
oint
> > because if you're like me, you kind of discover what's cool as you=

> > go. I may have a vague idea in mind, but on the road to that idea 
I
>=
 > see that something cool I hadn't thought of before pops up, so I 
go
> >=
 off in that direction instead. What matters most is what's good in
> > the=
 present.
> >
> > Now here is the connection to natural evolution: Natural =
evolution
> > is also completely unconcerned with ultimate goals or targets=
. It
> > only concerns itself with whether the present candidates are good =

in
> > the present.
> >
> > I am going to argue that that is a major sourc=
e of its power; it
> > explains in part its prolific creativity and its ast=
ounding 
ability
> > to elaborate indefinitely. Yes, I am claiming that it =
can do all
> > that because it *doesn't* have a target.
> >
> > So then wha=
t's so great about not having a target? What's great is
> > that you get re=
warded for doing what you *can* do. And a good
> > encoding can do a lot. H=
owever, what's very difficult, even for a
> > good encoding, is to do a com=
pletely arbitrary complex thing that 
is
> > nowhere close to the current p=
opulation in the search space.
> >
> > That is why I called TBE a liability=
: It evaluates the current
> > candidates against something that ignores th=
eir current strengths
> > completely. For example, imagine if the first bil=
ateria 
(bilaterally-
> > symmetric organisms) were evaluated for their hum=
anity. They would
> > all fail miserably and they would all therefore be el=
iminated.
> > Humanity would never have evolved even though we in fact did =

evolve
> > from the first bilateria! If TBE were in charge and humans were=
 
the
> > goal, we wouldn't exist right now.
> >
> > Try going back even fa=
rther. Can you imagine evaluating single
> > celled organisms for their "hu=
man-ness?" That would be silly.
> >
> > Yet that is exactly what we are doi=
ng in most evolutionary
> > experiments. We do nothing to capture good inte=
rmediate ideas from
> > which it would be possible to build our ultimate ob=
jectives. So we
> > are hampered from getting anywhere truly interesting.
>=
 >
> > Then you might ask, that's all well and good, but how in the world
>=
 > can we reward the intermediate serendipitous discoveries if we 
don't
> =
> know what they should be? The answer is: Respect the fact that you
> > do=
n't know what they are. Stop trying to *tell* evolution what it
> > can do =
and let it *show* you what it can do. When it shows you
> > something cool,=
 then keep that for later. Keep everything with any
> > promise for later. =
You never know what might be a foundation for 
the
> > next level up.
> >
>=
 > That's exactly what natural evolution did and that's exactly what 
IEC
>=
 > (Picbreeder variety) does: In nature what happened was that there
> > we=
re many ways of doing a good job (at surviving) and there was 
room
> > eno=
ugh on Earth to support a lot of them at once. Nobody "knew"
> > which ones=
 would form a good foundation for something more complex
> > (and many line=
ages didn't go anywhere), but because a lot of cool
> > ideas were able to =
hang around, some of them happened to be good
> > stepping stones to the ne=
xt big thing. The issue was where the DNA
> > encoding could go next from w=
here it is now.
> >
> > Same with IEC in Picbreeder: We don't know what we =
want to evolve
> > collectively. I think it's fair to say that we have no c=
ollective
> > common goal at all. We are all just trying different paths. S=
ome 
of
> > us, when we see a cool path, take that path a bit farther and a=
 
bit
> > farther still. We keep all the intermediate stages around forever=

> > and we therefore preserve all possible stepping stones. Some 
happen
>=
 > to be genuinely good foundations for future progress, like those 
that
>=
 > produced the car, or the recent skull. Yet who would have seen 
that
> >=
 coming? If we had tried to evolve to them from the start, we'd be
> > nowh=
ere (we'd be in the usual TBE trap).
> >
> > For this reason, what's going =
on in Picbreeder is really 
intriguing.
> > It's the first artificial evolu=
tionary experiment that is really
> > doing something like natural evolutio=
n! We may have some amazing
> > encodings out there, but we don't get to se=
e it because all we do 
is
> > TBE, where we keep losing the intermediate f=
oundations we would 
need
> > to get to a new level. Picbreeder is the firs=
t time that we let
> > evolution show us what it can do instead of telling =
it what we 
want
> > it to do. We are respecting the encoding just as natur=
e respected
> > DNA.
> >
> > There are some important corollaries: First, T=
BE is not just about
> > images. In effect, all regular fitness functions h=
ave the same TBE
> > liability. Do you think you can evolve an amazing neur=
al network
> > with NEAT or with HyperNEAT? Or something else? Well, if you=
 have 
a
> > target behavior that you evaluate against, you are never going=
 to
> > know how amazing things could be. This is a sobering realization.
>=
 > But it's just as true with behaviors as it is with images. (This
> > ins=
ight suggests that evolving behaviors interactively instead of
> > through =
a fitness function is a really promising path)
> >
> > One exception is com=
petitive coevolution, wherein individuals
> > actually are evaluated agains=
t other individuals, so it's not 
really
> > target-based. In a sense indiv=
iduals are recognized for being as
> > good as they can be in the present. =
Of course, nature is a kind of
> > coevolution.
> >
> > Yet I don't want to=
 pretend that competitive coevolution is the
> > perfect pathway to complex=
ity because the task may be defined in 
such
> > a way that it might as wel=
l be necessary to solve some gigantic
> > problem to become good. For examp=
le, competitive coevolution on Go
> > may not really end up rewarding indiv=
iduals for finding really 
basic
> > regularities that are necessary to eve=
ntually evolving a good Go
> > player.
> >
> > The key to natural evolution=
 was that there were a lot of easy 
ways
> > to do well in the beginning. S=
o we got a diversity of viable 
jumping
> > off points. That is also true o=
n Picbreeder: You can easily get a
> > picture that's good enough to be wor=
th showing others. So it's 
got a
> > very natural property: It proliferate=
s jumping-off points too.
> >
> > If you like, you can think of Picbreeder =
as an ecology where the
> > environment is just the preferences of its myri=
ad users. The
> > environment in nature is just Earth and physics. These ar=
e quite
> > different environments, but their effect on the dynamics of 
se=
lection
> > form an analogy. So at that level, it doesn't matter if a human=
 is
> > in the loop or not. What humans like is just the environment. And
>=
 > the nice things is, humans are very sensitive to regularity and
> > orga=
nization at all levels: exactly what a good environment should
> > reward i=
f we want to build up.
> >
> > I don't know where Picbreeder will go becaus=
e part of it depends 
on
> > how many users we get and how much they persev=
ere. So it may never
> > produce great works of art; I'd be surprised if it=
 did. Yet it has
> > these intriguing ingredients that we have not had befo=
re, so it 
is a
> > much more significant experiment than just a bunch of p=
eople 
playing
> > with an art toy.
> >
> > Hopefully this endless message =
answers the question with some 
extra
> > food for thought to boot. I know =
there are a lot of controversial
> > ideas here and please forgive me for n=
ot reminding you as I went 
that
> > many such claims were merely speculati=
on: I realize that they are,
> > but if I acknowledged that every time I sp=
eculated this near-novel
> > would be twice as long! You can be sure that I=
 am not trying to
> > present these ideas as settled facts by any means.
> =
>
> > ken
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <neat%40yahoogroups.com>, "De=
rek 
James"
> > <djames@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Ken wrote:
> > >
> > > > Of co=
urse the reason it was possible is because humans are 
doing
> > the
> > > =
> evaluation- which yields another lesson: The fitness function 
in
> > mos=
t
> > > > evolutionary computation is a liability against getting to 
high-=

> > level
> > > > complexity. There are deep reasons that human evaluation=
 is
> > actually
> > > > more analogous to what happened over natural evolu=
tion than 
any
> > other
> > > > type of evaluation scheme we run on comput=
ers. We are often 
misled
> > > > into believing that interactive evolution=
 is less "natural" 
than
> > > > normal EC. Actually, the opposite is true.=

> > >
> > > Like Jeff, I'd be interested in hearing you expand your 
thoug=
hts on
> > this. I
> > > think the demonstration is no less impressive, but=
 it seems to 
me
> > that the
> > > distinction between natural and artific=
ial selection is an 
important
> > > conceptual one. Natural selection is b=
ased on the attributes of 
the
> > > environment, while artificial selectio=
n is the result of 
attributes
> > selected
> > > by an agent (akin to anim=
al breeding or horticulture). In fact, 
in
> > The
> > > Origin of Species,=
 Darwin used many many examples of rapid
> > evolutionary
> > > change in d=
omesticated species such as pigeons and dogs to 
bolster
> > his
> > > argu=
ment for his theory.
> > >
> > > Maybe you're taking issue with the terms "=
natural"
> > and "artificial", and
> > > maybe there are better ways to mak=
e the distinction ("agent-
> > directed" vs.
> > > "environment-directed", =
"conscious" vs. "unconscious" 
evolution...I
> > don't
> > > know). But whi=
le I don't think artificial selection is any less
> > effective
> > > or po=
werful, probably moreso in some cases, I think it's useful 
to
> > maintain=

> > > that distinction.
> > >
> > > --Derek
> > >
